title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to tphconv
text: outlines propose change tphconv. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to tphconv
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to tphconv
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to tphconv
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("e-kotov/tphconv", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to tphconv
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to tphconv
text: Please note tphconv project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Egor Kotov. Author, maintainer, copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Kotov E (2025). tphconv: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data Rasters Vectors. R package version 0.1.0, https://github.com/e-kotov/tphconv.
code: @Manual{,   title = {tphconv: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors},   author = {Egor Kotov},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/e-kotov/tphconv}, }

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: tphconv R package converting public transport accessibility data Transport Poverty Hub raster vector spatial formats GISCO IDs. ’s designed : Read gzipped CSV files containing point-based accessibility measures (e.g., number people reachable within 10–20 minutes public transport). Reproject WGS84 (EPSG:4326) coordinates target grid (default EPSG:3035) perform necessary offset data line GISCO INSPIRE grids (https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/gisco/geodata/grids, https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/gisco/geodata/population-distribution/population-grids). Rasterize point data onto regular grid (e.g., 1 km resolution) generate vector polygon grids. Convert vector polygons analysis. Generate GISCO IDs grid cell, can useful linking datasets. makes easy integrate transport accessibility information GIS workflows analysis visualization.

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: can install development version tphconv GitHub:
code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("e-kotov/tphconv")

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: Accessibility data provided Transport Poverty Hub Dashboard, requires free EU account log . dashboard allows download precomputed CSV files 1 km grid various countries, including Luxembourg. downloaded file (e.g., ver1_0_LU_1km_pt_ppl_within_10-20_min.csv.gz), can point tphconv directly.

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: tph_to_raster() – Reads CSV, reprojects, rasterizes accessibility data SpatRaster writes disk out_raster_file specified (extensions supported terra). tph_to_vector() – Reads CSV, reprojects, converts accessibility data SpatVector sf object, writes disk out_vector_file specified (extensions supported sf, GPKG, GeoJSON, Shapefile, etc.). tph_to_table() – Reads CSV returns simple tibble GISCO IDs, optionally including centroid coordinates GISCO lower left corner coordinates.

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: defaults work long data provider change format CSV files. package designed handle standard format used Transport Poverty Hub, arguments can adjusted necessary.

what: Convert a CSV to a Raster
title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: Note raster layer also GISCO IDs default (can disabled add_id = FALSE). QGIS visible Raster Attribute Table, otherwise just another numeric layer labels.
code: library(tphconv)  # Locate the example data shipped with the package tph_file <- system.file(   "extdata",   "ver1_0_LU_1km_pt_ppl_within_10-20_min.csv.gz",   package = "tphconv" )  # Convert to a SpatRaster raster_layer <- tph_to_raster(input_file = tph_file)  library(terra) plot(raster_layer[[1]], main = "Transport Poverty Hub Accessibility Data") raster_layer class       : SpatRaster  size        : 81, 56, 2  (nrow, ncol, nlyr) resolution  : 1000, 1000  (x, y) extent      : 4015000, 4071000, 2934000, 3015000  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) coord. ref. : ETRS89-extended / LAEA Europe (EPSG:3035)  source(s)   : memory names       : opportunities_people,                        gisco_id  min values  :                    0, CRS3035RES1000mN3014000E4036000  max values  :                61065, CRS3035RES1000mN2934000E4057000

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
code: tmp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".tiff") output_path <- tph_to_raster(   input_file = tph_file,   out_raster_file = tmp_file )  # Check the output g <- terra::rast(output_path) g unlink(tmp_file) # Clean up temporary file class       : SpatRaster  size        : 81, 56, 2  (nrow, ncol, nlyr) resolution  : 1000, 1000  (x, y) extent      : 4015000, 4071000, 2934000, 3015000  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) coord. ref. : ETRS89-extended / LAEA Europe (EPSG:3035)  source      : file3d183d8ea354.tiff  names       : opportunities_people,                        gisco_id  min values  :                    0, CRS3035RES1000mN3014000E4036000  max values  :                61065, CRS3035RES1000mN2934000E4057000

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: Plots ommited brevity
code: library(tphconv)  # Locate the example data shipped with the package tph_file <- system.file(   "extdata",   "ver1_0_LU_1km_pt_ppl_within_10-20_min.csv.gz",   package = "tphconv" )  # Convert to a sf vector_layer_sf <- tph_to_vector(input_file = tph_file, return_as = "sf") plot(vector_layer_sf[, "opportunities_people"])  # Convert to a SpatVector library(terra) vector_layer_spat_vector <- tph_to_vector(   input_file = tph_file,   return_as = "SpatVector" ) plot(vector_layer_spat_vector, "opportunities_people")

title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
code: tmp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".gpkg") output_path <- tph_to_vector(   input_file = tph_file,   out_vector_file = tmp_file )  # Check the output g <- sf::read_sf(output_path) g unlink(tmp_file) # Clean up temporary file Simple feature collection with 1600 features and 2 fields Geometry type: POLYGON Dimension:     XY Bounding box:  xmin: 4015000 ymin: 2934000 xmax: 4071000 ymax: 3015000 Projected CRS: ETRS89-extended / LAEA Europe # A tibble: 1,600 × 3    opportunities_people gisco_id                                                   geom                   <dbl> <chr>                                             <POLYGON [m]>  1                 2625 CRS3035RES1000mN2934000E4033000 ((4033000 2934000, 4034000 293…  2                  375 CRS3035RES1000mN2934000E4057000 ((4057000 2934000, 4058000 293…  3                 7463 CRS3035RES1000mN2935000E4032000 ((4032000 2935000, 4033000 293…  4                10955 CRS3035RES1000mN2935000E4033000 ((4033000 2935000, 4034000 293…  5                 4087 CRS3035RES1000mN2935000E4034000 ((4034000 2935000, 4035000 293…  6                 4804 CRS3035RES1000mN2935000E4037000 ((4037000 2935000, 4038000 293…  7                  518 CRS3035RES1000mN2935000E4056000 ((4056000 2935000, 4057000 293…  8                  112 CRS3035RES1000mN2935000E4057000 ((4057000 2935000, 4058000 293…  9                 3515 CRS3035RES1000mN2936000E4032000 ((4032000 2936000, 4033000 293… 10                 7236 CRS3035RES1000mN2936000E4033000 ((4033000 2936000, 4034000 293… # ℹ 1,590 more rows # ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows

what: Convert to simple table with GISCO IDs
title: Convert Transport Poverty Hub Data to Rasters and Vectors
text: fastest function, create geometries, returns table original data GISCO IDs, optionally original coordinates centroids /coorindates GISCO lower left corners grid cells.
code: library(tphconv)  # Locate the example data shipped with the package tph_file <- system.file(   "extdata",   "ver1_0_LU_1km_pt_ppl_within_10-20_min.csv.gz",   package = "tphconv" )  # Convert to a tibble with GISCO IDs gisco_table <- tph_to_table(   input_file = tph_file,   add_centroid_coords = TRUE, # Optiona, Add centroid coordinates   add_gisco_corner_coords = TRUE # Optional, Add GISCO lower left corner coordinates )  head(gisco_table) gisco_id opportunities_people      lon      lat x_centroid y_centroid    x_ll    y_ll 1 CRS3035RES1000mN2934000E4033000                 2625 6.033336 49.45356    4033500    2934500 4033000 2934000 2 CRS3035RES1000mN2934000E4057000                  375 6.363958 49.46471    4057500    2934500 4057000 2934000 3 CRS3035RES1000mN2935000E4032000                 7463 6.018829 49.46205    4032500    2935500 4032000 2935000 4 CRS3035RES1000mN2935000E4033000                10955 6.032604 49.46254    4033500    2935500 4033000 2935000 5 CRS3035RES1000mN2935000E4034000                 4087 6.046380 49.46302    4034500    2935500 4034000 2935000 6 CRS3035RES1000mN2935000E4037000                 4804 6.087708 49.46447    4037500    2935500 4037000 2935000

text: gzipped CSV file 1 600 rows 3 columns: lat dbl; latitude (decimal degrees) lon dbl; longitude (decimal degrees) opportunities (people) dbl; number people reachable 10–20 min public transport

title: Example accessibility CSV for Luxembourg — data_luxembourg
text: Transport Poverty Hub © European Union, 1995–2025. Commission’s reuse policy implemented Commission Decision 12 December 2011 reuse Commission documents. Unless otherwise indicated, content owned EU website licensed Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC 4.0) licence. Reuse allowed, provided appropriate credit given changes indicated. information available : Recommendations Member States help tackle transport poverty promote fair, sustainable mobility Transport Poverty Hub (requires login free EU account)

title: Example accessibility CSV for Luxembourg — data_luxembourg

code: system.file(   "extdata",   "ver1_0_LU_1km_pt_ppl_within_10-20_min.csv.gz",   package = "tphconv" )

title: Example accessibility CSV for Luxembourg — data_luxembourg
code: f <- system.file(   "extdata",   "ver1_0_LU_1km_pt_ppl_within_10-20_min.csv.gz",   package = "tphconv" ) library(readr) acc <- read_csv(f) #> Rows: 1600 Columns: 3 #> ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Delimiter: "," #> dbl (3): lat, lon, opportunities (people) #>  #> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. #> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. head(acc) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>     lat   lon `opportunities (people)` #>   <dbl> <dbl>                    <dbl> #> 1  49.5  6.03                     2625 #> 2  49.5  6.36                      375 #> 3  49.5  6.02                     7463 #> 4  49.5  6.03                    10955 #> 5  49.5  6.05                     4087 #> 6  49.5  6.09                     4804

what: Generate INSPIRE / GISCO Grid-Cell IDs from Coordinates — generate_grid_id_from_coords
title: Generate INSPIRE / GISCO Grid-Cell IDs from Coordinates — generate_grid_id_from_coords
text: low-level helper function computes standardized grid-cell identifiers numeric coordinate vectors.

title: Generate INSPIRE / GISCO Grid-Cell IDs from Coordinates — generate_grid_id_from_coords
code: generate_grid_id_from_coords(xll, yll, cellsize, epsg, style, origin = c(0, 0))

title: Generate INSPIRE / GISCO Grid-Cell IDs from Coordinates — generate_grid_id_from_coords
text: xll numeric vector x-coordinates lower-left (south-west) corner cell. yll numeric vector y-coordinates lower-left (south-west) corner cell. cellsize grid resolution units coordinates. epsg integer EPSG code coordinate reference system. style format output ID string: "gisco_full" "gisco_short". origin numeric vector c(x, y) coordinates grid's origin.

title: Generate INSPIRE / GISCO Grid-Cell IDs from Coordinates — generate_grid_id_from_coords
text: character vector grid-cell IDs.

what: Generate INSPIRE / GISCO Grid-Cell IDs — tph_generage_grid_id
title: Generate INSPIRE / GISCO Grid-Cell IDs — tph_generage_grid_id
text: Computes standardized grid-cell identifiers SpatVector, SpatRaster, sf/sfc objects based lower-left (south-west) corner coordinates.

title: Generate INSPIRE / GISCO Grid-Cell IDs — tph_generage_grid_id
code: tph_generage_grid_id(   x,   cellsize = NULL,   crs = NULL,   style = c("gisco_full", "gisco_short"),   origin = c(0, 0),   raster_mask_na = FALSE,   raster_layer = 1 )

title: Generate INSPIRE / GISCO Grid-Cell IDs — tph_generage_grid_id
text: x SpatVector, SpatRaster, sf/sfc object. cellsize grid resolution units object's CRS (e.g., meters). NULL, inferred raster's resolution bounding box first vector feature (square). crs optional CRS string (e.g., "EPSG:3035") use object's CRS automatically determined. style format output ID string: "gisco_full" "gisco_short". origin numeric vector c(x, y) coordinates grid's origin. Defaults c(0, 0). raster_mask_na SpatRaster input, TRUE, IDs computed cells NA. raster_layer SpatRaster input, layer index use NA mask.

title: Generate INSPIRE / GISCO Grid-Cell IDs — tph_generage_grid_id
text: character vector grid-cell IDs. SpatRaster inputs, vector named corresponding cell indices.

title: Generate INSPIRE / GISCO Grid-Cell IDs — tph_generage_grid_id
text: function acts wrapper extracts coordinates various spatial object types passes core logic generate_grid_id_from_coords.

what: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Raster — tph_to_raster
title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Raster — tph_to_raster
text: Reads CSV file (optionally gzipped) public transport accessibility data, reprojects point coordinates, rasterizes data onto regular grid. Optionally, can add second raster layer containing INSPIRE-compliant grid cell IDs.

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Raster — tph_to_raster
code: tph_to_raster(   input_file,   out_column_name = NULL,   crs_src = 4326,   crs_dst = 3035,   x_offset = 0,   y_offset = 0,   resolution_m = 1000,   out_raster_file = NULL,   add_id = TRUE )

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Raster — tph_to_raster
text: input_file Character. Path input CSV (gzipped) containing least columns 'lon', 'lat', one numeric data column. out_column_name Character NULL. Name assign data column output raster. NULL (default), original column name CSV used. crs_src Integer character. Source CRS (EPSG code WKT); default 4326. crs_dst Integer character. Destination CRS (EPSG code WKT); default 3035. x_offset Numeric. offset subtracted projected x-coordinate. used convert source point's reference (e.g., lower-left corner) cell's theoretical centroid. centroid-based data like GISCO, default 0 correct. y_offset Numeric. offset subtracted projected y-coordinate, similar x_offset. resolution_m Numeric. Cell size units destination CRS; default 1000 (1 km). out_raster_file Character NULL. Output filename raster. provided, raster written file (creating directories needed) filename returned. NULL (default), SpatRaster returned directly. add_id Logical. TRUE (default), second layer named "id" added raster. factor layer labels correspond INSPIRE-compliant grid cell ID cell.

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Raster — tph_to_raster
text: out_raster_file NULL, terra::SpatRaster object. multi-layer raster add_id = TRUE. out_raster_file provided, character string file path returned.

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Raster — tph_to_raster
code: tph_file <- system.file(  "extdata",  "ver1_0_LU_1km_pt_ppl_within_10-20_min.csv.gz",  package = "tphconv" ) library(terra) #> terra 1.8.60  # Convert a CSV to a raster with the ID layer (default) r_with_id <- tph_to_raster(input_file = tph_file) plot(r_with_id)

what: Generate a Table of Grid IDs and Values from a TPH CSV — tph_to_table
title: Generate a Table of Grid IDs and Values from a TPH CSV — tph_to_table
text: Reads transport opportunities CSV file efficiently generates table containing corresponding INSPIRE/GISCO grid cell IDs data values.

title: Generate a Table of Grid IDs and Values from a TPH CSV — tph_to_table
code: tph_to_table(   input_file,   out_column_name = NULL,   crs_src = 4326,   crs_dst = 3035,   x_offset = -500,   y_offset = -500,   resolution_m = 1000,   add_centroid_coords = FALSE,   add_gisco_corner_coords = FALSE )

title: Generate a Table of Grid IDs and Values from a TPH CSV — tph_to_table
text: input_file Character. Path input CSV (gzipped) containing least columns 'lon', 'lat', one numeric data column. out_column_name Character NULL. Name assign data column output raster. NULL (default), original column name CSV used. crs_src Integer character. Source CRS (EPSG code WKT); default 4326. crs_dst Integer character. Destination CRS (EPSG code WKT); default 3035. x_offset Numeric. offset subtracted projected x-coordinate. used convert source point's reference (e.g., lower-left corner) cell's theoretical centroid. centroid-based data like GISCO, default 0 correct. y_offset Numeric. offset subtracted projected y-coordinate, similar x_offset. resolution_m Numeric. Cell size units destination CRS; default 1000 (1 km). add_centroid_coords Logical. TRUE, adds original lon lat well projected centroid coordinates (x_centroid, y_centroid) output table. Defaults FALSE. add_gisco_corner_coords Logical. TRUE, adds projected lower-left (south-west) corner coordinates (x_ll, y_ll) grid cell output table. Defaults FALSE.

title: Generate a Table of Grid IDs and Values from a TPH CSV — tph_to_table
text: data.frame gisco_id, data value, optional coordinate columns.

title: Generate a Table of Grid IDs and Values from a TPH CSV — tph_to_table
text: function fastest method converting TPH data, operates directly coordinates avoids creating intermediate spatial objects (rasters, polygons, sf points).

title: Generate a Table of Grid IDs and Values from a TPH CSV — tph_to_table

what: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Spatial Vector Object (Direct Method) — tph_to_vector
title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Spatial Vector Object (Direct Method) — tph_to_vector
text: Reads CSV file public transport accessibility data converts spatial vector format (sf terra::SpatVector). function builds polygon geometries directly point coordinates vectorized manner using sfheaders package, can faster sparse datasets methods requiring intermediate raster.

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Spatial Vector Object (Direct Method) — tph_to_vector
code: tph_to_vector(   input_file,   out_column_name = NULL,   crs_src = 4326,   crs_dst = 3035,   x_offset = -500,   y_offset = -500,   resolution_m = 1000,   out_vector_file = NULL,   return_as = c("sf", "SpatVector"),   add_id = TRUE )

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Spatial Vector Object (Direct Method) — tph_to_vector
text: input_file Character. Path input CSV (gzipped) containing least columns 'lon', 'lat', one numeric data column. out_column_name Character NULL. Name assign data column output raster. NULL (default), original column name CSV used. crs_src Integer character. Source CRS (EPSG code WKT); default 4326. crs_dst Integer character. Destination CRS (EPSG code WKT); default 3035. x_offset Numeric. offset subtracted projected x-coordinate. used convert source point's reference (e.g., lower-left corner) cell's theoretical centroid. centroid-based data like GISCO, default 0 correct. y_offset Numeric. offset subtracted projected y-coordinate, similar x_offset. resolution_m Numeric. Cell size units destination CRS; default 1000 (1 km). out_vector_file Character NULL. file path provided (e.g., "data/luxembourg.gpkg"), output written file using sf::st_write, file path returned. NULL (default), function returns -memory spatial object. return_as Character. Specifies class returned object out_vector_file NULL. Can either "sf" (default) "SpatVector". argument ignored out_vector_file NULL. add_id Logical. TRUE (default), INSPIRE-compliant grid cell ID generated added column named "id". Set FALSE omit step.

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Spatial Vector Object (Direct Method) — tph_to_vector
text: Depending arguments: out_vector_file NULL, returns sf object (default) SpatVector object (return_as = "SpatVector") polygon geometries. out_vector_file character string, path created file returned.

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Spatial Vector Object (Direct Method) — tph_to_vector
code: # This function requires the 'sfheaders' package if (requireNamespace("sfheaders", quietly = TRUE)) {   tph_file <- system.file(     "extdata",     "ver1_0_LU_1km_pt_ppl_within_10-20_min.csv.gz",     package = "tphconv"   )    # Convert a CSV file to an sf object using the direct method   sf_obj_direct <- tph_to_vector(input_file = tph_file)   plot(sf_obj_direct) }

what: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Spatial Vector Object via Raster — tph_to_vector_via_raster_slow
title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Spatial Vector Object via Raster — tph_to_vector_via_raster_slow
text: WARNING: function just prototype slow, first creates raster vectorizes . must found function accident, exported. Kindly, use tph_to_vector instead. Reads CSV file (optionally gzipped) public transport accessibility data converts spatial vector format (sf terra::SpatVector). function first rasterizes input point data onto regular grid converts raster cells polygons. INSPIRE-compliant grid cell ID can also generated polygon.

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Spatial Vector Object via Raster — tph_to_vector_via_raster_slow
code: tph_to_vector_via_raster_slow(   input_file,   out_column_name = NULL,   crs_src = 4326,   crs_dst = 3035,   x_offset = -500,   y_offset = -500,   resolution_m = 1000,   output_file = NULL,   return_as = c("sf", "SpatVector"),   add_id = TRUE )

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Spatial Vector Object via Raster — tph_to_vector_via_raster_slow
text: input_file Character. Path input CSV (gzipped) containing least columns 'lon', 'lat', one numeric data column. out_column_name Character NULL. Name assign data column output raster. NULL (default), original column name CSV used. crs_src Integer character. Source CRS (EPSG code WKT); default 4326. crs_dst Integer character. Destination CRS (EPSG code WKT); default 3035. x_offset Numeric. offset subtracted projected x-coordinate. used convert source point's reference (e.g., lower-left corner) cell's theoretical centroid. centroid-based data like GISCO, default 0 correct. y_offset Numeric. offset subtracted projected y-coordinate, similar x_offset. resolution_m Numeric. Cell size units destination CRS; default 1000 (1 km). output_file Character NULL. file path provided (e.g., "data/luxembourg.gpkg"), output written file using terra::writeVector, file path returned. NULL (default), function returns -memory spatial object. return_as Character. Specifies class returned object output_file NULL. Can either "sf" (default) "SpatVector". argument ignored output_file NULL. add_id Logical. TRUE (default), INSPIRE-compliant grid cell ID generated added column named "id". Set FALSE omit step.

title: Convert Transport Opportunities CSV to a Spatial Vector Object via Raster — tph_to_vector_via_raster_slow
text: Depending arguments: output_file NULL, returns sf object (default) SpatVector object (return_as = "SpatVector") polygon geometries. object include "id" column unless add_id FALSE. output_file character string, path created file returned.

title: tphconv 0.1.0 (2025-08-21)
text: Bugs fixed tph_to_raster, now grid correctly aligned reference GISCO grid. tph_to_raster now also generates GISCO grid IDs second layer raster. New function tph_to_vector convert TPH data vector formats. New function tph_to_table convert TPH data simple table data.frame.

title: tphconv 0.0.0.9000 (2025-08-06)
text: Initial draft.
